case.title: Width
case.description: Specify the button width. Use CSS syntax (e.g. 2in, 40px). Leave blank to use a default width.

case.title: Height

case.description: Force a column break before, after, or both before and after this control.

case.title: Break height
case.description: Specify the vertical distance between this control and the next control. Use CSS syntax. e.g. 10px, .5in, 20pt.

case.title: Repeating section heading
case.description: Specify the column heading for this control when it is displayed in a Repeating Section that shows labels on the first row only

case.title: Hide
case.description: Specify if this control should be hidden. Controls are typically hidden so that they can be manually placed into the Dialog HTML in a 'Free-form Container'.

case.title: Advanced button styling
case.description: Specify if you want more control over how the button appears. For example, you can put an image and text on the button. For touch applications (e.g. mobile applications), you should check this property.

case.title: Advanced button control type
case.description: Specify if the button should be displayed as a standard button, hyperlink, or image.
Button
Hyperlink
Image

case.title: Control container class name
case.description: (Advanced/Optional) All controls are automatically wrapped in a div (with a class name of 'A5CWLayout' or 'A5container' ) (unless the control is in a 'NoFloat' container). You can specify a class name to use for the control container in addition to the 'A5CWLayout' or 'A5container' class that is automatically used. This allows you to have more control over the appearance of the control.

case.title: Control container prevent float
case.description: (Advanced/Optional) All controls are automatically wrapped in a div (with a class name of 'A5CWLayout' or 'A5container' ) (unless the control is in a 'NoFloat' container). This container automatically 'floats' the control (so that your controls lay out automatically from left to right until a control with a 'break after' is encountered). In addition, the class adds padding around the control. By checking this property, the you are specifying that the div container that encloses this control will not have the 'A5CWLayout' or 'A5container' class applied.

case.title: Has dropdown icon
case.description: Specify if a small dropdown arrow should be shown on the button. (Typically only used if the button will open a dropdown window when clicked.)

case.title: Display as split button
case.description: Specify if the button should be split into two 'logical' buttons, with the button and the dropdown icon separated into two logical buttons. If you use this option you should define your event handler in the 'onClick' rather than the 'click' event. You will then be able to refer to arguments[1] in your code to see if the user clicked on the dropdown icon or the button. arguments[1] will be set to either 'normal' or 'split'.

case.title: Button text
case.description: Specify the text for the button. TIP:You can use the and language translation tags here.

case.title: Bubble help
case.description: Specify the bubble help for the button. The bubble help is displayed when the mouse is over the button. TIP:You can use the and language translation tags here.

case.title: Button class
case.description: Specify the button class. You can use for no class. Use or blank for the default class.

case.title: Button class hover
case.description: Button class when the mouse is hovering over the button. You can enter (or leave blank) to use the default class name. Specify for no class. If you specify your own class name here you can prefix it with '+' to use the specified class in addition to the default class. E.g. +myHoverclass.

case.title: Button class pressed
case.description: Button class when the user clicks on the button. You can enter (or leave blank) to use the default class name. Specify for no class. If you specify your own class name here you can prefix it with '+' to use the specified class in addition to the default class. E.g. +myPressedclass.

case.title: Button class disabled
case.description: Button class when the button is disabled. You can enter (or leave blank) to use the default class name. Specify for no class. If you specify your own class name here you can prefix it with '+' to use the specified class in addition to the default class. E.g. +myPisabledclass.
